addressleaf.section: A Monsieur Monsieur de Sidney Chevalier et governeur de la ville de Vlissingnes

page.lettertext:
fol.176r
S
r
Thomas Bodley to S
r
Robert Sydney
For want of good leasure to discourse as
I would, I send yo
r
L. heerew
t
e copie
of a letter, w
ch
I writte this morning unto
my
L. Treasurer
. I thinke
e party will
embarke at
Flushing,
and, as I am per-
suaded, will come to yo
r
L. Sins his going
from hens I doe learne that he is very
full of mony, to a greater summe then a
co
m
on souldier, and a man of his shewe is
wont to carie. His answear was to one
that sawe his money, that he had it of yo
r
L.
to pay at
e campe: w
ch
maketh me suspect
that he may
be
have bin hired for some worse
intent, then he pretendeth, and that he useth
my letter, but in steede of a passeport, to
gette in to
England.
I pray yo
r
L. if he
chance to come unto yo
w
, or otherwise
to
if
by enquirie yo
w
shall finde him in Flushing,
to examine him strictly, to suche purpose as
yo
r
self shall see cause, and if yo
w
finde it
requisit, to take my letter from him: and to
detene him till suche time, as yo
w
have adver-
tised my L. T
re
r of him: w
ch
I referre to
yo
r
L. wisdome. The man is of a lowe
stature, of
e age of 33 or thereabout, appa-
relled meanely, w
t
a cloke of
e collo
r
of
this bearers, a greene paire of nether stockes,
and an old embrodered sattin doublet.
O
r
campe this morning removed towardes
Groeninghen:
but their artillerie was em-
barked 4 daies before. If yo
r
L. pelase
to send yo
r
letters to
M
r
Copcot
, I have given
suche order, as he will send them very safely.
Fr
o
e Hage. June 6 1591.
Yo
r
L. ever and at co
m
aundem
t
Tho. Bodley.
